26.verse: The priests break my law and have no respect for what is holy. They make no distinction between what is holy and what is not. They do not teach the difference between clean and unclean things, and they ignore the Sabbath. As a result the people of Israel do not respect me.

27.verse: The government officials are like wolves tearing apart the animals they have killed. They commit murder in order to get rich.

28.verse: The prophets have hidden these sins like workers covering a wall with whitewash. They see false visions and make false predictions. They claim to speak the word of the Sovereign LORD, but I, the LORD, have not spoken to them.

29.verse: The wealthy cheat and rob. They mistreat the poor and take advantage of foreigners.

30.verse: I looked for someone who could build a wall, who could stand in the places where the walls have crumbled and defend the land when my anger is about to destroy it, but I could find no one.

31.verse: So I will turn my anger loose on them, and like a fire I will destroy them for what they have done.” The Sovereign LORD has spoken.

1.verse: The Sinful Sisters - The LORD spoke to me.

2.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “there were once two sisters.

3.verse: When they were young, living in Egypt, they lost their virginity and became prostitutes.

4.verse: The older one was named Oholah (she represents Samaria), and the younger one was named Oholibah (she represents Jerusalem). I married both of them, and they bore me children.

5.verse: Although she was mine, Oholah continued to be a prostitute and was full of lust for her lovers from Assyria.

6.verse: They were soldiers in uniforms of purple, noblemen and high-ranking officers; all of them were handsome young cavalry officers.

7.verse: She was the whore for all the Assyrian officers, and her lust led her to defile herself by worshiping Assyrian idols.

8.verse: She continued what she had begun as a prostitute in Egypt, where she lost her virginity. From the time she was a young woman, men slept with her and treated her like a prostitute.

9.verse: So I handed her over to her Assyrian lovers whom she wanted so much.

10.verse: They stripped her naked, seized her sons and daughters, and then killed her with a sword. Women everywhere gossiped about her fate.

11.verse: “Even though her sister Oholibah saw this, she was wilder and more of a prostitute than Oholah had ever been.

12.verse: She too was full of lust for the Assyrian noblemen and officers—soldiers in bright uniforms—and for the cavalry officers, all of those handsome young men.

13.verse: I saw that she was completely immoral, that the second sister was as bad as the first.

14.verse: “She sank deeper and deeper in her immorality. She was attracted by the images of high Babylonian officials carved into the wall and painted bright red, with sashes around their waists and fancy turbans on their heads.

15.verse: “She sank deeper and deeper in her immorality. She was attracted by the images of high Babylonian officials carved into the wall and painted bright red, with sashes around their waists and fancy turbans on their heads.

16.verse: As soon as she saw them, she was filled with lust and sent messengers to them in Babylonia.

17.verse: The Babylonians came to have sex with her. They used her and defiled her so much that finally she became disgusted with them.

18.verse: She exposed herself publicly and let everyone know she was a whore. I was as disgusted with her as I had been with her sister.

19.verse: She became more of a prostitute than ever, acting the way she did as a young woman, when she was a prostitute in Egypt.

20.verse: She was filled with lust for oversexed men who had all the lustfulness of donkeys or stallions.”

21.verse: ( Oholibah, you wanted to repeat the immorality you were guilty of as a young woman in Egypt, where men played with your breasts and you lost your virginity.)

22.verse: God's Judgment on the Younger Sister - “Now then, Oholibah, this is what I, the Sovereign LORD, am saying to you. You are tired of those lovers, but I will make them angry with you and bring them to surround you.

23.verse: I will bring all the Babylonians and Chaldeans, men from Pekod, Shoa, and Koa, and all the Assyrians. I will gather all those handsome young noblemen and officers, all those important officials and high-ranking cavalry officers.

24.verse: They will attack you from the north, bringing a large army with chariots and supply wagons. Protected by shields and helmets, they will surround you. I will hand you over to them, and they will judge you by their own laws.

25.verse: Because I am angry with you, I will let them deal with you in their anger. They will cut off your nose and your ears and kill your children. Yes, they will take your sons and daughters from you and burn them alive.

26.verse: They will tear off your clothes and take your jewels.

27.verse: I will put a stop to your lust and to the obscenities you have committed ever since you were in Egypt. You won't look at any more idols or think about Egypt any more.”

28.verse: This is what the Sovereign LORD says: “I will hand you over to people you hate and are disgusted with.

29.verse: And because they hate you, they will take away everything you have worked for and leave you stripped naked, exposed like a prostitute. Your lust and your prostitution

30.verse: have brought this on you. You were a prostitute for the nations and defiled yourself with their idols.

31.verse: You followed in your sister's footsteps, and so I will give you the same cup of punishment to drink.”

32.verse: The Sovereign LORD says, “You will drink from your sister's cup; it is large and deep. Everyone will scorn and mock you; the cup is full.

33.verse: It will make you miserable and drunk, that cup of fear and ruin, your sister Samaria's cup.

34.verse: You will drink and drain it dry, and with its broken pieces tear your breast. I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken.”

35.verse: Now this is what the Sovereign LORD is saying: “Because you forgot me and turned your back on me, you will suffer for your lust and your prostitution.”

36.verse: God's Judgment on Both Sisters - The LORD said to me, “Mortal man, are you ready to judge Oholah and Oholibah? Accuse them of the disgusting things they have done.

37.verse: They have committed adultery and murder—adultery with idols and murder of the children they bore me. They sacrificed my children to their idols.

38.verse: And that is not all they did. They profaned my Temple and broke the Sabbath, which I had established.

39.verse: The very day that they killed my children as sacrifices to idols, they came to my Temple and profaned it!

40.verse: “Again and again they sent messengers to invite men to come from a great distance, and the men came. The two sisters would bathe and put on eye shadow and jewelry.

41.verse: They would sit on a beautiful couch, and in front of them they would have a table covered with good things, including the incense and the olive oil that I had given them.

42.verse: The sound of a carefree crowd could be heard, a group of men brought in from the desert. They put bracelets on the women's arms and beautiful crowns on their heads.

43.verse: And I said to myself that they were using as a prostitute a woman worn out by adultery.

44.verse: They went back to these prostitutes again and again. They went back to Oholah and Oholibah, those immoral women.

45.verse: Righteous men will condemn them on the charge of adultery and murder, because they practice adultery and their hands are stained with blood.”

46.verse: This is what the Sovereign LORD says: “Bring a mob to terrorize them and rob them.

47.verse: Let the mob stone them and attack them with swords, kill their children, and burn down their houses.

48.verse: Throughout the land I will put a stop to immorality, as a warning to every woman not to commit adultery as they did.

49.verse: And you two sisters—I will punish you for your immorality and your sin of worshiping idols. Then you will know that I am the Sovereign LORD.”

1.verse: The Corroded Cooking Pot - On the tenth day of the tenth month of the ninth year of our exile, the LORD spoke to me.

2.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “write down today's date, because this is the day that the king of Babylonia is beginning the siege of Jerusalem.

3.verse: Tell my rebellious people this parable that I, the Sovereign LORD, have for them: Set the pot on the fire and fill it up with water.

4.verse: Put in the best pieces of meat— the shoulders and the legs— fill it with choice bony pieces too.

5.verse: Use the meat of the finest sheep; pile the wood under the pot. Let the water boil; boil the bones and the meat.”

6.verse: This is what the Sovereign LORD is saying: “The city of murderers is doomed! It is like a corroded pot that is never cleaned. Piece after piece of meat is taken out, and not one is left.

7.verse: There was murder in the city, but the blood was not spilled on the ground where the dust could hide it; it was spilled on a bare rock.

8.verse: I have left the blood there, where it cannot be hidden, where it demands angry revenge.”

9.verse: This is what the Sovereign LORD is saying: “The city of murderers is doomed! I myself will pile up the firewood.

10.verse: Bring more wood! Fan the flames! Cook the meat! Boil away the broth! Burn up the bones!

11.verse: Now set the empty bronze pot on the coals and let it get red-hot. Then the pot will be ritually pure again after the corrosion is burned off,

12.verse: although all that corrosion will not disappear in the flames.

13.verse: Jerusalem, your immoral actions have defiled you. Although I tried to purify you, you remained defiled. You will not be pure again until you have felt the full force of my anger.

14.verse: I, the LORD, have spoken. The time has come for me to act. I will not ignore your sins or show pity or be merciful. You will be punished for what you have done.” The Sovereign LORD has spoken.

15.verse: The Death of the Prophet's Wife - The LORD spoke to me.

16.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “with one blow I am going to take away the person you love most. You are not to complain or cry or shed any tears.

17.verse: Don't let your sobbing be heard. Do not go bareheaded or barefoot as a sign of mourning. Don't cover your face or eat the food that mourners eat.”

18.verse: Early in the day I was talking with the people. That evening my wife died, and the next day I did as I had been told.

19.verse: The people asked me, “Why are you acting like this?”

20.verse: So I said to them, “The LORD spoke to me and told me

21.verse: to give you Israelites this message: You are proud of the strength of the Temple. You like to look at it and to visit it, but the LORD is going to profane it. And the younger members of your families who are left in Jerusalem will be killed in war.

22.verse: Then you will do what I have done. You will not cover your faces or eat the food that mourners eat.

23.verse: You will not go bareheaded or barefoot or mourn or cry. You will waste away because of your sins, and you will groan to one another.

24.verse: Then I will be a sign to you; you will do everything I have done. The LORD says that when this happens, you will know that he is the Sovereign LORD.”

25.verse: The LORD said, “Now, mortal man, I will take away from them the strong Temple that was their pride and joy, which they liked to look at and to visit. And I will take away their sons and daughters.

26.verse: On the day that I do this, some who escape the destruction will come and tell you about it.

27.verse: That same day you will get back the power of speech which you had lost, and you will talk with them. In this way you will be a sign to the people, and they will know that I am the LORD.”

1.verse: Prophecy against Ammon - The LORD spoke to me.

2.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “denounce the country of Ammon.

3.verse: Tell them to listen to what I, the Sovereign LORD, am saying: You were delighted to see my Temple profaned, to see the land of Israel devastated, to see the people of Judah go into exile.

4.verse: Because you were glad, I will let the tribes from the eastern desert conquer you. They will set up their camps in your country and settle there. They will eat the fruit and drink the milk that should have been yours.

5.verse: I will turn the city of Rabbah into a place to keep camels, and the whole country of Ammon will become a place to keep sheep, so that you will know I am the LORD.

6.verse: “This is what the Sovereign LORD is saying: You clapped your hands and jumped for joy. You despised the land of Israel.

7.verse: Because you did, I will hand you over to other nations who will rob you and plunder you. I will destroy you so completely that you will not be a nation any more or have a country of your own. Then you will know that I am the LORD.”

8.verse: Prophecy against Moab - The Sovereign LORD said, “Because Moab has said that Judah is like all the other nations,

9.verse: I will let the cities that defend the border of Moab be attacked, including even the finest cities—Beth Jeshimoth, Baal Meon, and Kiriathaim.

10.verse: I will let the tribes of the eastern desert conquer Moab, together with Ammon, so that Moab will no longer be a nation.

11.verse: I will punish Moab, and they will know that I am the LORD.”

12.verse: Prophecy against Edom - The Sovereign LORD said, “The people of Edom took cruel revenge on Judah, and that revenge has brought lasting guilt on Edom.

13.verse: Now I announce that I will punish Edom and kill every person and animal there. I will make it a wasteland, from the city of Teman to the city of Dedan, and the people will be killed in battle.

14.verse: My people Israel will take revenge on Edom for me, and they will make Edom feel my furious anger. Edom will know what it means to be the object of my revenge.” The Sovereign LORD has spoken.

15.verse: Prophecy against Philistia - The Sovereign LORD said, “The Philistines have taken cruel revenge on their agelong enemies and destroyed them in their hate.

16.verse: And so I am announcing that I will attack the Philistines and wipe them out. I will destroy everyone left living there on the Philistine Plain.

17.verse: I will punish them severely and take full revenge on them. They will feel my anger. Then they will know that I am the LORD.”

1.verse: Prophecy against Tyre - On the first day of the … month of the eleventh year of our exile, the LORD spoke to me.

2.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “this is what the people in the city of Tyre are cheering about. They shout, ‘Jerusalem is shattered! Her commercial power is gone! She won't be our rival any more!’

3.verse: “Now then, this is what I, the Sovereign LORD, am saying: I am your enemy, city of Tyre. I will bring many nations to attack you, and they will come like the waves of the sea.

4.verse: They will destroy your city walls and tear down your towers. Then I will sweep away all the dust and leave only a bare rock.

5.verse: Fishermen will dry their nets on it, there where it stands in the sea. I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken. The nations will plunder Tyre,

6.verse: and with their swords they will kill those who live in her towns on the mainland. Then Tyre will know that I am the LORD.”

7.verse: The Sovereign LORD says, “I am going to bring the greatest king of all—King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia—to attack Tyre. He will come from the north with a huge army, with horses and chariots and with cavalry.

8.verse: Those who live in the towns on the mainland will be killed in the fighting. The enemy will dig trenches, build earthworks, and make a solid wall of shields against you.

9.verse: They will pound in your walls with battering rams and tear down your towers with iron bars.

10.verse: The clouds of dust raised by their horses will cover you. The noise of their horses pulling wagons and chariots will shake your walls as they pass through the gates of the ruined city.

11.verse: Their cavalry will storm through your streets, killing your people with their swords. Your mighty pillars will be thrown to the ground.

12.verse: Your enemies will help themselves to your wealth and merchandise. They will pull down your walls and shatter your luxurious houses. They will take the stones and wood and all the rubble, and dump them into the sea.

13.verse: I will put an end to all your songs, and I will silence the music of your harps.

14.verse: I will leave only a bare rock where fishermen can dry their nets. The city will never be rebuilt. I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken.”

15.verse: The Sovereign LORD has this to say to the city of Tyre: “When you are being conquered, the people who live along the coast will be terrified at the screams of those who are slaughtered.

16.verse: All the kings of the seafaring nations will come down from their thrones. They will take off their robes and their embroidered clothes and sit trembling on the ground. They will be so terrified at your fate that they will not be able to stop trembling.

17.verse: They will sing this funeral song for you: The famous city is destroyed! Her ships have been swept from the seas. The people of this city ruled the seas And terrified all who lived on the coast.

18.verse: Now, on the day it has fallen, The islands are trembling, And their people are shocked at such destruction.”

19.verse: The Sovereign LORD says: “I will make you as desolate as ruined cities where no one lives. I will cover you with the water of the ocean depths.

20.verse: I will send you down to the world of the dead to join the people who lived in ancient times. I will make you stay in that underground world among eternal ruins, keeping company with the dead. As a result you will never again be inhabited and take your place in the land of the living.

21.verse: I will make you a terrifying example, and that will be the end of you. People may look for you, but you will never be found.” The Sovereign LORD has spoken.

1.verse: A Funeral Song for Tyre - The LORD said to me,

2.verse: “Mortal man, sing a funeral song for Tyre,

3.verse: that city which stands at the edge of the sea and does business with the people living on every seacoast. Tell her what the Sovereign LORD is saying: “Tyre, you boasted of your perfect beauty.

4.verse: Your home is the sea. Your builders made you like a beautiful ship;

5.verse: They used fir trees from Mount Hermon for timber And a cedar from Lebanon for your mast.

6.verse: They took oak trees from Bashan to make oars; They made your deck out of pine from Cyprus And inlaid it with ivory.

7.verse: Your sails were made of linen, Embroidered linen from Egypt, Easily recognized from afar. Your awnings were made of finest cloth, Of purple from the island of Cyprus.

8.verse: Your oarsmen were from the cities of Sidon and Arvad. Your own skillful men were the sailors.

9.verse: The ship's carpenters Were well-trained men from Byblos. Sailors from every seagoing ship Did business in your shops.

10.verse: “Soldiers from Persia, Lydia, and Libya served in your army. They hung their shields and their helmets in your barracks. They are the men who won glory for you.

11.verse: Soldiers from Arvad guarded your walls, and troops from Gamad guarded your towers. They hung their shields on your walls. They are the ones who made you beautiful.

12.verse: “You did business in Spain and took silver, iron, tin, and lead in payment for your abundant goods.

13.verse: You did business in Greece, Tubal, and Meshech and traded your goods for slaves and for articles of bronze.

14.verse: You sold your goods for workhorses, war-horses, and mules from Beth Togarmah.

15.verse: The people of Rhodes traded with you; people of many coastal lands gave you ivory and ebony in exchange for your goods.

16.verse: The people of Syria bought your merchandise and your many products. They gave emeralds, purple cloth, embroidery, fine linen, coral, and rubies in payment for your wares.

17.verse: Judah and Israel paid for your goods with wheat, honey, olive oil, and spices.

18.verse: The people of Damascus bought your merchandise and your products, paying for them with wine from Helbon and wool from Sahar. They traded wrought iron and spices for your goods.

19.verse: The people of Damascus bought your merchandise and your products, paying for them with wine from Helbon and wool from Sahar. They traded wrought iron and spices for your goods.

20.verse: The people of Dedan traded saddle blankets for your goods.

21.verse: The Arabians and the rulers of the land of Kedar paid for your merchandise with lambs, sheep, and goats.

22.verse: For your goods the merchants of Sheba and Raamah traded jewels, gold, and the finest spices.

23.verse: The cities of Haran, Canneh, and Eden, the merchants of Sheba, the cities of Asshur and Chilmad—they all traded with you.

24.verse: They sold you luxurious clothing, purple cloth, and embroidery, brightly colored carpets, and well-made cords and ropes.

25.verse: Your merchandise was carried in fleets of the largest cargo ships. “You were like a ship at sea Loaded with heavy cargo.

26.verse: When your oarsmen brought you out to sea, An east wind wrecked you far from land.

27.verse: All your wealth of merchandise, All the sailors in your crew, Your ship's carpenters and your merchants, Every soldier on board the ship— All, all were lost at sea When your ship was wrecked.

28.verse: The shouts of the drowning sailors Echoed on the shore.

29.verse: “Every ship is now deserted, And every sailor has gone ashore.

30.verse: They all mourn bitterly for you, Throwing dust on their heads and rolling in ashes.

31.verse: They shave their heads for you And dress themselves in sackcloth. Their hearts are bitter as they weep.

32.verse: They chant a funeral song for you: ‘Who can be compared to Tyre, To Tyre now silent in the sea?

33.verse: When your merchandise went overseas, You filled the needs of every nation. Kings were made rich By the wealth of your goods.

34.verse: Now you are wrecked in the sea; You have sunk to the ocean depths. Your goods and all who worked for you Have vanished with you in the sea.’

35.verse: “Everyone who lives along the coast is shocked at your fate. Even their kings are terrified, and fear is written on their faces.

36.verse: You are gone, gone forever, and merchants all over the world are terrified, afraid that they will share your fate.”

1.verse: Prophecy against the King of Tyre - The LORD spoke to me.

2.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “tell the ruler of Tyre what I, the Sovereign LORD, am saying to him: Puffed up with pride, you claim to be a god. You say that like a god you sit on a throne, surrounded by the seas. You may pretend to be a god, but, no, you are mortal, not divine.

3.verse: You think you are wiser than Danel, that no secret can be kept from you.

4.verse: Your wisdom and skill made you rich with treasures of gold and silver.

5.verse: You made clever business deals and kept on making profits. How proud you are of your wealth!

6.verse: “Now then, this is what I, the Sovereign LORD, am saying: Because you think you are as wise as a god,

7.verse: I will bring ruthless enemies to attack you. They will destroy all the beautiful things you have acquired by skill and wisdom.

8.verse: They will kill you and send you to a watery grave.

9.verse: When they come to kill you, will you still claim that you are a god? When you face your murderers, you will be mortal and not at all divine.

10.verse: You will die like a dog at the hand of godless foreigners. I, the Sovereign LORD, have given the command.”

11.verse: The Fall of the King of Tyre - The LORD spoke to me again.

12.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “grieve for the fate that is waiting for the king of Tyre. Tell him what I, the Sovereign LORD, am saying: You were once an example of perfection. How wise and handsome you were!

13.verse: You lived in Eden, the garden of God, and wore gems of every kind: rubies and diamonds; topaz, beryl, carnelian, and jasper; sapphires, emeralds, and garnets. You had ornaments of gold. They were made for you on the day you were created.

14.verse: I put a terrifying angel there to guard you. You lived on my holy mountain and walked among sparkling gems.

15.verse: Your conduct was perfect from the day you were created until you began to do evil.

16.verse: You were busy buying and selling, and this led you to violence and sin. So I forced you to leave my holy mountain, and the angel who guarded you drove you away from the sparkling gems.

17.verse: You were proud of being handsome, and your fame made you act like a fool. Because of this I hurled you to the ground and left you as a warning to other kings.

18.verse: You did such evil in buying and selling that your places of worship were corrupted. So I set fire to the city and burned it to the ground. All who look at you now see you reduced to ashes.

19.verse: You are gone, gone forever, and all the nations that had come to know you are terrified, afraid that they will share your fate.”

20.verse: Prophecy against Sidon - The LORD said to me,

21.verse: “Mortal man, denounce the city of Sidon.

22.verse: Tell the people there what I, the Sovereign LORD, say about them: I am your enemy, Sidon; people will praise me because of what I do to you. They will know that I am the LORD, when I show how holy I am by punishing those who live in you.

23.verse: I will send diseases on you and make blood flow in your streets. You will be attacked from every side, and your people will be killed. Then you will know that I am the LORD.”

24.verse: Israel Will Be Blessed - The LORD said, “None of the surrounding nations that treated Israel with scorn will ever again be like thorns and briers to hurt Israel. And they will know that I am the Sovereign LORD.”

25.verse: The Sovereign LORD said, “I will bring back the people of Israel from the nations where I scattered them, and all the nations will know that I am holy. The people of Israel will live in their own land, the land that I gave to my servant Jacob.

26.verse: They will live there in safety. They will build houses and plant vineyards. I will punish all their neighbors who treated them with scorn, and Israel will be secure. Then they will know that I am the LORD their God.”

1.verse: Prophecy against Egypt - On the twelfth day of the tenth month of the tenth year of our exile, the LORD spoke to me.

2.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “denounce the king of Egypt. Tell him how he and all the land of Egypt will be punished.

3.verse: Say that this is what the Sovereign LORD is telling the king of Egypt: I am your enemy, you monster crocodile, lying in the river. You say that the Nile is yours and that you made it.

4.verse: I am going to put a hook through your jaw and make the fish in your river stick fast to you. Then I will pull you up out of the Nile, with all the fish sticking to you.

5.verse: I will throw you and all those fish into the desert. Your body will fall on the ground and be left unburied. I will give it to the birds and animals for food.

6.verse: Then all the people of Egypt will know that I am the LORD.” The LORD says, “The Israelites relied on you Egyptians for support, but you were no better than a weak stick.

7.verse: When they leaned on you, you broke, pierced their armpits, and made them wrench their backs.

8.verse: Now then, I, the Sovereign LORD, am telling you that I will have troops attack you with swords, and they will kill your people and your animals.

9.verse: Egypt will become an empty wasteland. Then you will know that I am the LORD. “Because you said that the Nile is yours and you made it,

10.verse: I am your enemy and the enemy of your Nile. I will make all of Egypt an empty wasteland, from the city of Migdol in the north to the city of Aswan in the south, all the way to the Ethiopian border.

11.verse: No human being or animal will walk through it. For forty years nothing will live there.

12.verse: I will make Egypt the most desolate country in the world. For forty years the cities of Egypt will lie in ruins, ruins worse than those of any other city. I will make the Egyptians refugees. They will flee to every country and live among other peoples.”

13.verse: The Sovereign LORD says, “After forty years I will bring the Egyptians back from the nations where I have scattered them,

14.verse: and I will let them live in southern Egypt, their original home. There they will be a weak kingdom,

15.verse: the weakest kingdom of all, and they will never again rule other nations. I will make them so unimportant that they will not be able to bend any other nation to their will.

16.verse: Israel will never again depend on them for help. Egypt's fate will remind Israel how wrong it was to rely on them. Then Israel will know that I am the Sovereign LORD.”

17.verse: King Nebuchadnezzar Will Conquer Egypt - On the first day of the first month of the twenty-seventh year of our exile, the LORD spoke to me.

18.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia launched an attack on Tyre. He made his soldiers carry such heavy loads that their heads were rubbed bald and their shoulders were worn raw, but neither the king nor his army got anything for all their trouble.

19.verse: So now this is what I, the Sovereign LORD, am saying: I am giving the land of Egypt to King Nebuchadnezzar. He will loot and plunder it and carry off all the wealth of Egypt as his army's pay.

20.verse: I am giving him Egypt in payment for his services, because his army was working for me. I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken.

21.verse: “When that happens, I will make the people of Israel strong and let you, Ezekiel, speak out where everyone can hear you, so that they will know that I am the LORD.”

1.verse: The Lord Will Punish Egypt - The LORD spoke to me again.

2.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “prophesy and announce what I, the Sovereign LORD, am saying. You are to shout these words: A day of terror is coming!

3.verse: The day is near, the day when the LORD will act, A day of clouds and trouble for the nations.

4.verse: There will be war in Egypt And great distress in Ethiopia. Many in Egypt will be killed; The country will be plundered And left in ruins.

5.verse: “That war will also kill the soldiers hired from Ethiopia, Libya, Lydia, Arabia, Kub, and even from among my own people.”

6.verse: The LORD says, “From Migdol in the north to Aswan in the south, all Egypt's defenders will be killed in battle. Egypt's proud army will be destroyed. I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken.

7.verse: The land will be the most desolate in the world, and its cities will be left totally in ruins.

8.verse: When I set fire to Egypt and all her defenders are killed, then they will know that I am the LORD.

9.verse: “When that day comes and Egypt is destroyed, I will send messengers in ships to arouse the unsuspecting people of Ethiopia, and they will be terrified. That day is coming!”

10.verse: The Sovereign LORD says, “I will use King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia to put an end to Egypt's wealth.

11.verse: He and his ruthless army will come to devastate the land. They will attack Egypt with swords, and the land will be full of corpses.

12.verse: I will dry up the Nile and put Egypt under the power of evil people. Foreigners will devastate the whole country. I, the LORD, have spoken.”

13.verse: The Sovereign LORD says, “I will destroy the idols and the false gods in Memphis. There will be no one to rule Egypt, and I will terrify all the people.

14.verse: I will make southern Egypt desolate and set fire to the city of Zoan in the north. I will punish the capital city of Thebes.

15.verse: I will let the city of Pelusium, Egypt's great fortress, feel my fury. I will destroy the wealth of Thebes.

16.verse: I will set fire to Egypt, and Pelusium will be in agony. The walls of Thebes will be broken down, and the city will be flooded.

17.verse: The young men of the cities of Heliopolis and Bubastis will die in the war, and the other people will be taken prisoner.

18.verse: Darkness will fall on Tahpanhes when I break the power of Egypt and put an end to the strength they were so proud of. A cloud will cover Egypt, and the people of all her cities will be taken prisoner.

19.verse: When I punish Egypt in this way, they will know that I am the LORD.”

20.verse: The Broken Power of the King of Egypt - On the seventh day of the first month of the eleventh year of our exile, the LORD spoke to me.

21.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “I have broken the arm of the king of Egypt. No one has bandaged it or put it in a sling so that it could heal and be strong enough to hold a sword again.

22.verse: Now then, this is what I, the Sovereign LORD, say: I am the enemy of the king of Egypt. I am going to break both his arms—the good one and the one already broken—and the sword will fall from his hand.

23.verse: I am going to scatter the Egyptians throughout the world.

24.verse: Then I will make the arms of the king of Babylonia strong and put my sword in his hands. But I will break the arms of the king of Egypt, and he will groan and die in front of his enemy.

25.verse: Yes, I will weaken him and strengthen the king of Babylonia. When I give him my sword and he points it toward Egypt, everyone will know that I am the LORD.

26.verse: I will scatter the Egyptians throughout the world. Then they will know that I am the LORD.”

1.verse: Egypt Is Compared to a Cedar Tree - On the first day of the third month of the eleventh year of our exile, the LORD spoke to me.

2.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “say to the king of Egypt and all his people: How powerful you are! What can I compare you to?

3.verse: You are like a cedar in Lebanon, With beautiful, shady branches, A tree so tall it reaches the clouds.

4.verse: There was water to make it grow, And underground rivers to feed it. They watered the place where the tree was growing And sent streams to all the trees of the forest.

5.verse: Because it was well-watered, It grew taller than other trees. Its branches grew thick and long.

6.verse: Every kind of bird built nests in its branches; The wild animals bore their young in its shelter; The nations of the world rested in its shade.

7.verse: How beautiful the tree was— So tall, with such long branches. Its roots reached down to the deep-flowing streams.

8.verse: No cedar in God's garden could compare with it. No fir tree ever had such branches, And no plane tree such limbs. No tree in God's own garden was so beautiful.

9.verse: I made it beautiful, with spreading branches. It was the envy of every tree in Eden, the garden of God.

10.verse: “Now then, I, the Sovereign LORD, will tell you what is going to happen to that tree that grew until it reached the clouds. As it grew taller it grew proud;

11.verse: so I have rejected it and will let a foreign ruler have it. He will give that tree what it deserves for its wickedness.

12.verse: Ruthless foreigners will cut it down and leave it. Its branches and broken limbs will fall on every mountain and valley in the country. All the nations that have been living in its shade will go away.

13.verse: The birds will come and perch on the fallen tree, and the wild animals will walk over its branches.

14.verse: And so from now on, no tree, no matter how well-watered it is, will grow that tall again or push its top through the clouds and reach such a height. All of them are doomed to die like mortals, doomed to join those who go down to the world of the dead.”

15.verse: This is what the Sovereign LORD says: “On the day when the tree goes to the world of the dead, I will make the underground waters cover it as a sign of mourning. I will hold back the rivers and not let the many streams flow out. Because the tree has died, I will bring darkness over the Lebanon Mountains and make all the trees of the forest wither.

16.verse: When I send it down to the world of the dead, the noise of its downfall will shake the nations. All the trees of Eden and all the choice, well-watered trees of Lebanon who have gone to the world below will be pleased at its downfall.

17.verse: They will go with it to the world of the dead to join those that have already fallen. And all who live under its shadow will be scattered among the nations.

18.verse: “The tree is the king of Egypt and all his people. Not even the trees in Eden were so tall and impressive. But now, like the trees of Eden, it will go down to the world of the dead and join the ungodly and those killed in battle. I have spoken,” says the Sovereign LORD.

1.verse: The King of Egypt Is Compared to a Crocodile - On the first day of the twelfth month of the twelfth year of our exile, the LORD spoke to me.

2.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “give a solemn warning to the king of Egypt. Give him this message from me: You act like a lion among the nations, but you are more like a crocodile splashing through a river. You muddy the water with your feet and pollute the rivers.

3.verse: When many nations gather, I will catch you in my net and let them drag the net ashore.

4.verse: I will throw you out on the ground and bring all the birds and animals of the world to feed on you.

5.verse: I will cover mountains and valleys with your rotting corpse.

6.verse: I will pour out your blood until it spreads over the mountains and fills the streams.

7.verse: When I destroy you, I will cover the sky and blot out the stars. The sun will hide behind the clouds, and the moon will give no light.

8.verse: I will put out all the lights of heaven and plunge your world into darkness. I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken.

9.verse: “Many nations will be troubled when I spread the news of your destruction through countries you never heard of.

10.verse: What I do to you will shock many nations. When I swing my sword, kings will shudder with fright. On the day you fall, all of them will tremble in fear for their own lives.”

11.verse: The Sovereign LORD says to the king of Egypt, “You will face the sword of the king of Babylonia.

12.verse: I will let soldiers from cruel nations draw their swords and kill all your people. All your people and everything else that you are proud of will be destroyed.

13.verse: I will slaughter your cattle at every water hole. There will be no people or cattle to muddy the water any more.

14.verse: I will let your waters settle and become clear and let your rivers run calm. I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken.

15.verse: When I make Egypt a desolate wasteland and destroy all who live there, they will know that I am the LORD.

16.verse: This solemn warning will become a funeral song. The women of the nations will sing it to mourn for Egypt and all its people. I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken.”

17.verse: The World of the Dead - On the fifteenth day of the first month of the twelfth year of our exile, the LORD spoke to me.

18.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “mourn for all the many people of Egypt. Send them down with the other powerful nations to the world of the dead.

19.verse: Say to them: “Do you think you are more beautiful than anyone else? You will go down to the world of the dead and lie there among the ungodly.

20.verse: “The people of Egypt will fall with those who are killed in battle. A sword is ready to kill them all.

21.verse: The greatest heroes and those who fought on the Egyptian side welcome the Egyptians to the world of the dead. They shout: ‘The ungodly who were killed in battle have come down here, and here they lie!’

22.verse: “Assyria is there, with the graves of her soldiers all around. They were all killed in battle,

23.verse: and their graves are in the deepest parts of the world of the dead. All her soldiers fell in battle, and their graves surround her tomb. Yet once they terrified the land of the living.

24.verse: “Elam is there, with the graves of her soldiers all around. They were all killed in battle, and they went down, uncircumcised, to the world of the dead. In life they spread terror, but now they lie dead and disgraced.

25.verse: Elam lies down among those killed in battle, and the graves of her soldiers are all around her. They are all uncircumcised, all killed in battle. In life they spread terror, but now they lie dead and disgraced, sharing the fate of those killed in battle.

26.verse: “Meshech and Tubal are there, with the graves of their soldiers all around. They are all uncircumcised, all killed in battle. Yet once they terrified the living.

27.verse: They were not given honorable burial like the heroes of ancient times, who went fully armed to the world of the dead, their swords placed under their heads and their shields over their bodies. These heroes were once powerful enough to terrify the living.

28.verse: “That is how the Egyptians will lie crushed among the uncircumcised who were killed in battle.

29.verse: “Edom is there with her kings and rulers. They were powerful soldiers, but now they lie in the world of the dead with the uncircumcised who were killed in battle.

30.verse: “All the princes of the north are there, and so are the Sidonians. Their power once spread terror, but now they go down in disgrace with those killed in battle and are laid to rest, uncircumcised. They share the disgrace of those who go down to the world of the dead.

31.verse: “The sight of all these who were killed in battle will be a comfort to the king of Egypt and his army,” says the Sovereign LORD.

32.verse: “I caused the king of Egypt to terrorize the living, but he and all his army will be killed and laid to rest with all the uncircumcised who die in battle.” The Sovereign LORD has spoken.

1.verse: God Appoints Ezekiel as a Lookout - The LORD spoke to me.

2.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “tell your people what happens when I bring war to a land. The people of that country choose one of their number to be a lookout.

3.verse: When he sees the enemy approaching, he sounds the alarm to warn everyone.

4.verse: If someone hears it but pays no attention and the enemy comes and kills him, then he is to blame for his own death.

5.verse: His death is his own fault, because he paid no attention to the warning. If he had paid attention, he could have escaped.

6.verse: If, however, the lookout sees the enemy coming and does not sound the alarm, the enemy will come and kill those sinners, but I will hold the lookout responsible for their death.

7.verse: “Now, mortal man, I am making you a lookout for the nation of Israel. You must pass on to them the warnings I give you.

8.verse: If I announce that an evil person is going to die but you do not warn him to change his ways so that he can save his life, then he will die, still a sinner, and I will hold you responsible for his death.

9.verse: If you do warn an evil person and he doesn't stop sinning, he will die, still a sinner, but your life will be spared.”

10.verse: Individual Responsibility - The LORD spoke to me. “Mortal man,” he said, “repeat to the Israelites what they are saying: ‘We are burdened with our sins and the wrongs we have done. We are wasting away. How can we live?’

11.verse: Tell them that as surely as I, the Sovereign LORD, am the living God, I do not enjoy seeing sinners die. I would rather see them stop sinning and live. Israel, stop the evil you are doing. Why do you want to die?

12.verse: “Now, mortal man, tell the Israelites that when someone good sins, the good he has done will not save him. If an evil person stops doing evil, he won't be punished, and if a good man starts sinning, his life will not be spared.

13.verse: I may promise life to someone good, but if he starts thinking that his past goodness is enough and begins to sin, I will not remember any of the good he did. He will die because of his sins.

14.verse: I may warn someone evil that he is going to die, but if he stops sinning and does what is right and good—

15.verse: for example, if he returns the security he took for a loan or gives back what he stole—if he stops sinning and follows the laws that give life, he will not die, but live.

16.verse: I will forgive the sins he has committed, and he will live because he has done what is right and good.

17.verse: “And your people say that what I do isn't right! No, it's their way that isn't right.

18.verse: When someone righteous stops doing good and starts doing evil, he will die for it.

19.verse: When someone evil quits sinning and does what is right and good, he has saved his life.

20.verse: But Israel, you say that what I do isn't right. I am going to judge you by what you do.”

21.verse: The News of Jerusalem's Fall - On the fifth day of the tenth month of the twelfth year of our exile, someone who had escaped from Jerusalem came and told me that the city had fallen.

22.verse: The evening before he came, I had felt the powerful presence of the LORD. When the man arrived the next morning, the LORD gave me back the power of speech.

23.verse: The Sins of the People - The LORD spoke to me.

24.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “the people who are living in the ruined cities of the land of Israel are saying: ‘Abraham was only one man, and he was given the whole land. There are many of us, so now the land is ours.’

25.verse: “Tell them what I, the Sovereign LORD, am saying: You eat meat with the blood still in it. You worship idols. You commit murder. What makes you think that the land belongs to you?

26.verse: You rely on your swords. Your actions are disgusting. Everyone commits adultery. What makes you think that the land is yours?

27.verse: “Tell them that I, the Sovereign LORD, warn them that as surely as I am the living God, the people who live in the ruined cities will be killed. Those living in the country will be eaten by wild animals. Those hiding in the mountains and in caves will die of disease.

28.verse: I will make the country a desolate wasteland, and the power they were so proud of will come to an end. The mountains of Israel will be so wild that no one will be able to travel through them.

29.verse: When I punish the people for their sins and make the country a wasteland, then they will know that I am the LORD.”

30.verse: The Results of the Prophet's Message - The LORD said, “Mortal man, your people are talking about you when they meet by the city walls or in the doorways of their houses. They say to one another, ‘Let's go and hear what word has come from the LORD now.’

31.verse: So my people crowd in to hear what you have to say, but they don't do what you tell them to do. Loving words are on their lips, but they continue their greedy ways.

32.verse: To them you are nothing more than an entertainer singing love songs or playing a harp. They listen to all your words and don't obey a single one of them.

33.verse: But when all your words come true—and they will come true—then they will know that a prophet has been among them.”

1.verse: The Shepherds of Israel - The LORD spoke to me.

2.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “denounce the rulers of Israel. Prophesy to them, and tell them what I, the Sovereign LORD, say to them: You are doomed, you shepherds of Israel! You take care of yourselves, but never tend the sheep.

3.verse: You drink the milk, wear clothes made from the wool, and kill and eat the finest sheep. But you never tend the sheep.

4.verse: You have not taken care of the weak ones, healed the ones that are sick, bandaged the ones that are hurt, brought back the ones that wandered off, or looked for the ones that were lost. Instead, you treated them cruelly.

5.verse: Because the sheep had no shepherd, they were scattered, and wild animals killed and ate them.

6.verse: So my sheep wandered over the high hills and the mountains. They were scattered over the face of the earth, and no one looked for them or tried to find them.

7.verse: “Now, you shepherds, listen to what I, the LORD, am telling you.

8.verse: As surely as I am the living God, you had better listen to me. My sheep have been attacked by wild animals that killed and ate them because there was no shepherd. My shepherds did not try to find the sheep. They were taking care of themselves and not the sheep.

9.verse: So listen to me, you shepherds.

10.verse: I, the Sovereign LORD, declare that I am your enemy. I will take my sheep away from you and never again let you be their shepherds; never again will I let you take care only of yourselves. I will rescue my sheep from you and not let you eat them.

11.verse: The Good Shepherd - “I, the Sovereign LORD, tell you that I myself will look for my sheep and take care of them

12.verse: in the same way as shepherds take care of their sheep that were scattered and are brought together again. I will bring them back from all the places where they were scattered on that dark, disastrous day.

13.verse: I will take them out of foreign countries, gather them together, and bring them back to their own land. I will lead them back to the mountains and the streams of Israel and will feed them in pleasant pastures.

14.verse: I will let them graze in safety in the mountain meadows and the valleys and in all the green pastures of the land of Israel.

15.verse: I myself will be the shepherd of my sheep, and I will find them a place to rest. I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken.

16.verse: “I will look for those that are lost, bring back those that wander off, bandage those that are hurt, and heal those that are sick; but those that are fat and strong I will destroy, because I am a shepherd who does what is right.

17.verse: “Now then, my flock, I, the Sovereign LORD, tell you that I will judge each of you and separate the good from the bad, the sheep from the goats.

18.verse: Some of you are not satisfied with eating the best grass; you even trample down what you don't eat! You drink the clear water and muddy what you don't drink!

19.verse: My other sheep have to eat the grass you trample down and drink the water you muddy.

20.verse: “So now, I, the Sovereign LORD, tell you that I will judge between you strong sheep and the weak sheep.

21.verse: You pushed the sick ones aside and butted them away from the flock.

22.verse: But I will rescue my sheep and not let them be mistreated any more. I will judge each of my sheep and separate the good from the bad.

23.verse: I will give them a king like my servant David to be their one shepherd, and he will take care of them.

24.verse: I, the LORD, will be their God, and a king like my servant David will be their ruler. I have spoken.

25.verse: I will make a covenant with them that guarantees their security. I will get rid of all the dangerous animals in the land, so that my sheep can live safely in the fields and sleep in the forests.

26.verse: “I will bless them and let them live around my sacred hill. There I will bless them with showers of rain when they need it.

27.verse: The trees will bear fruit, the fields will produce crops, and everyone will live in safety on his own land. When I break my people's chains and set them free from those who made them slaves, then they will know that I am the LORD.

28.verse: The heathen nations will not plunder them any more, and the wild animals will not kill and eat them. They will live in safety, and no one will terrify them.

29.verse: I will give them fertile fields and put an end to hunger in the land. The other nations will not sneer at them any more.

30.verse: Everyone will know that I protect Israel and that they are my people. I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken.

31.verse: “You, my sheep, the flock that I feed, are my people, and I am your God,” says the Sovereign LORD.

1.verse: God's Punishment of Edom - The LORD spoke to me.

2.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “denounce the country of Edom.

3.verse: Tell the people what I, the Sovereign LORD, am saying: “I am your enemy, mountains of Edom! I will make you a desolate wasteland.

4.verse: I will leave your cities in ruins And your land desolate; Then you will know that I am the LORD.

5.verse: “You were Israel's constant enemy and let her people be slaughtered in the time of her disaster, the time of final punishment for her sins.

6.verse: So then—as surely as I, the Sovereign LORD, am the living God—death is your fate, and you cannot escape it. You are guilty of murder, and murder will follow you.

7.verse: I will make the hill country of Edom a wasteland and kill everyone who travels through it.

8.verse: I will cover the mountains with corpses, and the bodies of those who are killed in battle will cover the hills and valleys.

9.verse: I will make you desolate forever, and no one will live in your cities again. Then you will know that I am the LORD.

10.verse: “You said that the two nations, Judah and Israel, together with their lands, belonged to you and that you would possess them, even though I, the LORD, was their God.

11.verse: So then, as surely as I, the Sovereign LORD, am the living God, I will pay you back for your anger, your jealousy, and your hate toward my people. They will know that I am punishing you for what you did to them.

12.verse: Then you will know that I, the LORD, heard you say with contempt that the mountains of Israel were desolate and that they were yours to devour.

13.verse: I have heard the wild, boastful way you have talked against me.”

14.verse: The Sovereign LORD says, “I will make you so desolate that the whole world will rejoice at your downfall,

15.verse: just as you rejoiced at the devastation of Israel, my own possession. The mountains of Seir, yes, all the land of Edom, will be desolate. Then everyone will know that I am the LORD.”

1.verse: God's Blessing on Israel - The LORD said, “Mortal man, speak to the mountains of Israel and tell them to listen to the message which I,

2.verse: the Sovereign LORD, have for them: Israel's enemies gloated and said, ‘Now those ancient hills are ours!’

3.verse: “Prophesy, then, and announce what I, the Sovereign LORD, am saying. When the neighboring nations captured and plundered the mountains of Israel, everyone made fun of Israel.

4.verse: So now listen to what I, the Sovereign LORD, say to you mountains and hills, to you brooks and valleys, to you places that were left in ruins, and to you deserted cities which were plundered and mocked by all the surrounding nations.

5.verse: “I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken out in the heat of my anger against the surrounding nations, and especially against Edom. With glee and contempt they captured my land and took possession of its pastures.

6.verse: “So prophesy to the land of Israel; tell the mountains, hills, brooks, and valleys what I, the Sovereign LORD, am saying in jealous anger because of the way the nations have insulted and humiliated them.

7.verse: I, the Sovereign LORD, solemnly promise that the surrounding nations will be humiliated.

8.verse: But on the mountains of Israel the trees will again grow leaves and bear fruit for you, my people Israel. You are going to come home soon.

9.verse: I am on your side, and I will make sure that your land is plowed again and crops are planted on it.

10.verse: I will make your population grow. You will live in the cities and rebuild everything that was left in ruins.

11.verse: I will make people and cattle increase in number. There will be more of you than ever before, and you will have many children. I will let you live there as you used to live, and I will make you more prosperous than ever. Then you will know that I am the LORD.

12.verse: I will bring you, my people Israel, back to live again in the land. It will be your own land, and it will never again let your children starve.

13.verse: “I, the Sovereign LORD, say: It is true that people say that the land eats people and that it robs the nation of its children.

14.verse: But from now on it will no longer eat people and rob you of your children. I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken.

15.verse: The land will no longer have to listen to the nations making fun of it or see the peoples sneer at it. The land will no longer rob the nation of its children. I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken.”

16.verse: Israel's New Life - The LORD spoke to me.

17.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “when the Israelites were living in their land, they defiled it by the way they lived and acted. I regarded their behavior as being as ritually unclean as a woman is during her monthly period.

18.verse: I let them feel the force of my anger because of the murders they had committed in the land and because of the idols by which they had defiled it.

19.verse: I condemned them for the way they lived and acted, and I scattered them through foreign countries.

20.verse: Wherever they went, they brought disgrace on my holy name, because people would say, ‘These are the people of the LORD, but they had to leave his land.’

21.verse: That made me concerned for my holy name, since the Israelites brought disgrace on it everywhere they went.

22.verse: “Now then, give the Israelites the message that I, the Sovereign LORD, have for them: What I am going to do is not for the sake of you Israelites, but for the sake of my holy name, which you have disgraced in every country where you have gone.

23.verse: When I demonstrate to the nations the holiness of my great name—the name you disgraced among them—then they will know that I am the LORD. I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken. I will use you to show the nations that I am holy.

24.verse: I will take you from every nation and country and bring you back to your own land.

25.verse: I will sprinkle clean water on you and make you clean from all your idols and everything else that has defiled you.

26.verse: I will give you a new heart and a new mind. I will take away your stubborn heart of stone and give you an obedient heart.

27.verse: I will put my spirit in you and will see to it that you follow my laws and keep all the commands I have given you.

28.verse: Then you will live in the land I gave your ancestors. You will be my people, and I will be your God.

29.verse: I will save you from everything that defiles you. I will command the grain to be plentiful, so that you will not have any more famines.

30.verse: I will increase the yield of your fruit trees and your fields, so that there will be no more famines to disgrace you among the nations.

31.verse: You will remember your evil conduct and the wrongs that you committed, and you will be disgusted with yourselves because of your sins and your iniquities.

32.verse: Israel, I want you to know that I am not doing all this for your sake. I want you to feel the shame and disgrace of what you are doing. I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken.”

33.verse: The Sovereign LORD says, “When I make you clean from all your sins, I will let you live in your cities again and let you rebuild the ruins.

34.verse: Everyone who used to walk by your fields saw how overgrown and wild they were, but I will let you farm them again.

35.verse: Everyone will talk about how this land, which was once a wilderness, has become like the Garden of Eden, and how the cities which were torn down, looted, and left in ruins, are now inhabited and fortified.

36.verse: Then the neighboring nations that have survived will know that I, the LORD, rebuild ruined cities and replant waste fields. I, the LORD, have promised that I would do this—and I will.”

37.verse: The Sovereign LORD says, “I will once again let the Israelites ask me for help, and I will let them increase in numbers like a flock of sheep.

38.verse: The cities that are now in ruins will then be as full of people as Jerusalem was once full of the sheep which were offered as sacrifices at a festival. Then they will know that I am the LORD.”

1.verse: The Valley of Dry Bones - I felt the powerful presence of the LORD, and his spirit took me and set me down in a valley where the ground was covered with bones.

2.verse: He led me all around the valley, and I could see that there were very many bones and that they were very dry.

3.verse: He said to me, “Mortal man, can these bones come back to life?” I replied, “Sovereign LORD, only you can answer that!”

4.verse: He said, “Prophesy to the bones. Tell these dry bones to listen to the word of the LORD.

5.verse: Tell them that I, the Sovereign LORD, am saying to them: I am going to put breath into you and bring you back to life.

6.verse: I will give you sinews and muscles, and cover you with skin. I will put breath into you and bring you back to life. Then you will know that I am the LORD.”

7.verse: So I prophesied as I had been told. While I was speaking, I heard a rattling noise, and the bones began to join together.

8.verse: While I watched, the bones were covered with sinews and muscles, and then with skin. But there was no breath in the bodies.

9.verse: God said to me, “Mortal man, prophesy to the wind. Tell the wind that the Sovereign LORD commands it to come from every direction, to breathe into these dead bodies, and to bring them back to life.”

10.verse: So I prophesied as I had been told. Breath entered the bodies, and they came to life and stood up. There were enough of them to form an army.

11.verse: God said to me, “Mortal man, the people of Israel are like these bones. They say that they are dried up, without any hope and with no future.

12.verse: So prophesy to my people Israel and tell them that I, the Sovereign LORD, am going to open their graves. I am going to take them out and bring them back to the land of Israel.

13.verse: When I open the graves where my people are buried and bring them out, they will know that I am the LORD.

14.verse: I will put my breath in them, bring them back to life, and let them live in their own land. Then they will know that I am the LORD. I have promised that I would do this—and I will. I, the LORD, have spoken.”

15.verse: Judah and Israel in One Kingdom - The LORD spoke to me again.

16.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “take a wooden stick and write on it the words, ‘The kingdom of Judah.’ Then take another stick and write on it the words, ‘The kingdom of Israel.’

17.verse: Then hold the two sticks end to end in your hand so that they look like one stick.

18.verse: When your people ask you to tell them what this means,

19.verse: tell them that I, the Sovereign LORD, am going to take the stick representing Israel and put it with the one that represents Judah. Out of the two I will make one stick and hold it in my hand.

20.verse: “Hold in your hand the two sticks and let the people see them.

21.verse: Then tell them that I, the Sovereign LORD, am going to take all my people out of the nations where they have gone, gather them together, and bring them back to their own land.

22.verse: I will unite them into one nation in the land, on the mountains of Israel. They will have one king to rule over them, and they will no longer be divided into two nations or split into two kingdoms.

23.verse: They will not defile themselves with disgusting idols any more or corrupt themselves with sin. I will free them from all the ways in which they sin and betray me. I will purify them; they will be my people, and I will be their God.

24.verse: A king like my servant David will be their king. They will all be united under one ruler and will obey my laws faithfully.

25.verse: They will live on the land I gave to my servant Jacob, the land where their ancestors lived. They will live there forever, and so will their children and all their descendants. A king like my servant David will rule them forever.

26.verse: I will make a covenant with them that guarantees their security forever. I will establish them and increase their population, and will see to it that my Temple stands forever in their land.

27.verse: I will live there with them; I will be their God, and they will be my people.

28.verse: When I place my Temple there to be among them forever, then the nations will know that I, the LORD, have chosen Israel to be my own people.”

1.verse: Gog as the Instrument of God - The LORD spoke to me.

2.verse: “Mortal man,” he said, “denounce Gog, chief ruler of the nations of Meshech and Tubal in the land of Magog. Denounce him

3.verse: and tell him that I, the Sovereign LORD, am his enemy.

4.verse: I will turn him around, put hooks in his jaws, and drag him and all his troops away. His army, with its horses and uniformed riders, is enormous, and every soldier carries a shield and is armed with a sword.

5.verse: Troops from Persia, Ethiopia, and Libya are with him, and all have shields and helmets.

6.verse: All the fighting men of the lands of Gomer and Beth Togarmah in the north are with him, and so are men from many other nations.

7.verse: Tell him to get ready and have all his troops ready at his command.

8.verse: After many years I will order him to invade a country where the people were brought back together from many nations and have lived without fear of war. He will invade the mountains of Israel, which were desolate and deserted so long, but where all the people now live in safety.

9.verse: He and his army and the many nations with him will attack like a storm and cover the land like a cloud.”

10.verse: This is what the Sovereign LORD says to Gog: “When that time comes, you will start thinking up an evil plan.

11.verse: You will decide to invade a helpless country where the people live in peace and security in unwalled towns that have no defenses.

12.verse: You will plunder and loot the people who live in cities that were once in ruins. They have been gathered from the nations, and now they have livestock and property and live at the crossroads of the world.

13.verse: The people of Sheba and Dedan and the merchants from the towns of Spain will ask you, ‘Have you assembled your army and attacked in order to loot and plunder? Do you intend to get silver and gold, livestock and property, and march off with all those spoils?’”

14.verse: So the Sovereign LORD sent me to tell Gog what he was saying to him: “Now while my people Israel live in security, you will set out

15.verse: to come from your place in the far north, leading a large, powerful army of soldiers from many nations, all of them on horseback.

16.verse: You will attack my people Israel like a storm moving across the land. When the time comes, I will send you to invade my land in order to show the nations who I am, to show my holiness by what I do through you.

17.verse: You are the one I was talking about long ago, when I announced through my servants, the prophets of Israel, that in days to come I would bring someone to attack Israel.” The Sovereign LORD has spoken.

18.verse: God's Punishment of Gog - The Sovereign LORD says, “On the day when Gog invades Israel, I will become furious.

19.verse: I declare in the heat of my anger that on that day there will be a severe earthquake in the land of Israel.

20.verse: Every fish and bird, every animal large and small, and every human being on the face of the earth will tremble for fear of me. Mountains will fall, cliffs will crumble, and every wall will collapse.

21.verse: I will terrify Gog with all sorts of calamities. I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken. His men will turn their swords against one another.

22.verse: I will punish him with disease and bloodshed. Torrents of rain and hail, together with fire and sulfur, will pour down on him and his army and on the many nations that are on his side.

23.verse: In this way I will show all the nations that I am great and that I am holy. They will know then that I am the LORD.”

1.verse: The Defeat of Gog - The Sovereign LORD said, “Mortal man, denounce Gog, the chief ruler of the nations of Meshech and Tubal, and tell him that I am his enemy.

2.verse: I will turn him in a new direction and lead him out of the far north until he comes to the mountains of Israel.

3.verse: Then I will knock his bow out of his left hand and his arrows out of his right hand.

4.verse: Gog and his army and his allies will fall dead on the mountains of Israel, and I will let their bodies be food for all the birds and wild animals.

5.verse: They will fall dead in the open field. I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken.

6.verse: I will start a fire in the land of Magog and along all the seacoasts where people live undisturbed, and everyone will know that I am the LORD.

7.verse: I will make sure that my people Israel know my holy name, and I will not let my name be disgraced any more. Then the nations will know that I, the LORD, am the holy God of Israel.”

8.verse: The Sovereign LORD said, “The day I spoke about is certain to come.

9.verse: The people who live in the cities of Israel will go out and collect the abandoned weapons for firewood. They will build fires with the shields, bows, arrows, spears, and clubs, and have enough to last for seven years.

10.verse: They will not have to gather firewood in the fields or cut down trees in the forest, because they will have the abandoned weapons to burn. They will loot and plunder those who looted and plundered them.” The Sovereign LORD has spoken.

11.verse: The Burial of Gog - The LORD said, “When all this happens, I will give Gog a burial ground there in Israel, in Travelers' Valley, east of the Dead Sea. Gog and all his army will be buried there, and the valley will be called ‘The Valley of Gog's Army.’

12.verse: It will take the Israelites seven months to bury all the corpses and make the land clean again.

13.verse: Everyone in the land will help bury them, and they will be honored for this on the day of my victory. I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken.

14.verse: After the seven months are over, men will be chosen to travel through the land in order to find and bury those bodies remaining on the ground, so that they can make the land clean.

15.verse: As they go up and down the country, every time they find a human bone, they will put a marker beside it so that the gravediggers can come and bury it in the Valley of Gog's Army.

16.verse: (There will be a town nearby named after the army.) And so the land will be made clean again.”

17.verse: The Sovereign LORD said to me, “Mortal man, call all the birds and animals to come from all around to eat the sacrifice I am preparing for them. It will be a huge feast on the mountains of Israel, where they can eat meat and drink blood.

18.verse: They are to eat the bodies of soldiers and drink the blood of the rulers of the earth, all of whom will be killed like rams or lambs or goats or fat bulls.

19.verse: When I kill these people like sacrifices, the birds and animals are to eat all the fat they can hold and to drink blood until they are drunk.

20.verse: At my table they will eat all they can hold of horses and their riders and of soldiers and fighting men. I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken.”

21.verse: The Restoration of Israel - The LORD said, “I will let the nations see my glory and show them how I use my power to carry out my just decisions.

22.verse: The Israelites will know from then on that I am the LORD their God.

23.verse: And the nations will know that the Israelites went into exile because of the sins which they committed against me. I turned away from them and let their enemies defeat them and kill them in battle.

24.verse: I gave them what they deserved for their uncleanness and their wickedness, and I turned away from them.”

25.verse: The Sovereign LORD said, “But now I will be merciful to Jacob's descendants, the people of Israel, and make them prosperous again. I will protect my holy name.

26.verse: When they are once more living in safety in their own land, with no one to threaten them, they will be able to forget how they were disgraced for having betrayed me.

27.verse: In order to show to the many nations that I am holy, I will bring my people back from all the countries where their enemies live.

28.verse: Then my people will know that I am the LORD their God. They will know this, because I sent them into captivity and now gather them and bring them back into their own land, not leaving even one of them behind.

29.verse: I will pour out my spirit on the people of Israel and never again turn away from them. I, the Sovereign LORD, have spoken.”

1.verse: A VISION OF THE FUTURE TEMPLE (40.1— 48.35) Ezekiel Is Taken to Jerusalem - It was the tenth day of the new year, which was the twenty-fifth year after we had been taken into exile and the fourteenth year after Jerusalem was captured. On that day I felt the powerful presence of the LORD, and he carried me away.

2.verse: In a vision God took me to the land of Israel and put me on a high mountain. I saw in front of me a group of buildings that looked like a city.

3.verse: He took me closer, and I saw a man who shone like bronze. He was holding a linen tape measure and a measuring rod and was standing by a gateway.

4.verse: He said to me, “Watch, mortal man. Listen carefully and pay close attention to everything I show you, because this is why you were brought here. You are to tell the people of Israel everything you see.”

5.verse: The East Gate - What I saw was the Temple, and there was a wall around it. The man took his measuring rod, which was 10 feet long, and measured the wall. It was 10 feet high and 10 feet thick.

6.verse: Then he went to the gateway that faced east. He went up the steps, and at the top he measured the entrance; it was 10 feet deep.

7.verse: Beyond it there was a passageway, which had three guardrooms on each side. Each of the rooms was square, 10 feet on each side, and the walls between them were 8 feet thick. Beyond the guardrooms there was a passageway 10 feet long that led to an entrance room which faced the Temple.

8.verse: He measured this room and found it was 14 feet deep. It formed that end of the gateway which was nearest the Temple, and at its far end the walls were 4 feet thick.

9.verse: He measured this room and found it was 14 feet deep. It formed that end of the gateway which was nearest the Temple, and at its far end the walls were 4 feet thick.

10.verse: ( These guardrooms on each side of the passageway were all the same size, and the walls between them were all of the same thickness.)

11.verse: Next, the man measured the width of the passageway in the gateway. It was 22 feet altogether, and the space between the open gates was 16 feet.

12.verse: In front of each of the guardrooms there was a low wall 20 inches high and 20 inches thick. (The rooms were 10 feet square.)

13.verse: Then he measured the distance from the back wall of one room to the back wall of the room across the passageway from it, and it was 42 feet.

14.verse: The room at the far end led out to a courtyard. He measured that room and found it was 34 feet wide.

15.verse: The total length of the gateway from the outside wall of the gate to the far side of the last room was 84 feet.

16.verse: There were small openings in the outside walls of all the rooms and also in the inner walls between the rooms. There were palm trees carved on the inner walls that faced the passageway.

17.verse: The Outer Courtyard - The man took me through the gateway into the courtyard. There were thirty rooms built against the outer wall, and in front of them there was an area paved with stones,

18.verse: which extended around the courtyard. This outer courtyard was at a lower level than the inner courtyard.

19.verse: There was a gateway at a higher level that led to the inner courtyard. The man measured the distance between the two gateways, and it was 168 feet.

20.verse: The North Gate - Then the man measured the gateway on the north side that led into the outer courtyard.

21.verse: The three guardrooms on each side of the passageway, the walls between them, and the entrance room all had the same measurements as those in the east gateway. The total length of the gateway was 84 feet and the width 42 feet.

22.verse: The entrance room, the windows, and the carved palm trees were like those in the east gate. Here seven steps led up to the gate, and the entrance room was at the end facing the courtyard.

23.verse: Across the courtyard from this north gateway was another gateway leading to the inner courtyard, just as there was on the east side. The man measured the distance between these two gateways, and it was 168 feet.

24.verse: The South Gate - Next, the man took me to the south side, and there we saw another gateway. He measured its inner walls and its entrance room, and they were the same as the others.

25.verse: There were windows in the rooms of this gateway just as in the others. The total length of the gateway was 84 feet and the width 42 feet.

26.verse: Seven steps led up to it, and its entrance room was also at the end facing the courtyard. There were palm trees carved on the inner walls that faced the passageway.

27.verse: Here, too, there was a gateway leading to the inner courtyard. The man measured the distance to this second gateway, and it was 168 feet.

28.verse: The Inner Courtyard: The South Gate - The man took me through the south gateway into the inner courtyard. He measured the gateway, and it was the same size as the gateways in the outer wall.

29.verse: Its guardrooms, its entrance room, and its inner walls were the same size as those in the other gateways. There were also windows in the rooms of this gateway. The total length was 84 feet and the width 42 feet.

30.verse: Its guardrooms, its entrance room, and its inner walls were the same size as those in the other gateways. There were also windows in the rooms of this gateway. The total length was 84 feet and the width 42 feet.

31.verse: Its entrance room faced the other courtyard, and palm trees were carved on the walls along the passageway. Eight steps led up to this gate.

32.verse: The Inner Courtyard: The East Gate - The man took me through the east gateway into the inner courtyard. He measured the gateway, and it was the same size as the others.

33.verse: Its guardrooms, its entrance room, and its inner walls measured the same as those in the other gateways. There were windows all around, and in the entrance room also. The total length was 84 feet and the width 42 feet.

34.verse: The entrance room faced the outer courtyard. Palm trees were carved on the walls along the passageway. Eight steps led up to this gate.

35.verse: The Inner Courtyard: The North Gate - Then the man took me to the north gateway. He measured it, and it was the same size as the others.

36.verse: Like them, it also had guardrooms, decorated inner walls, an entrance room, and windows all around. Its total length was 84 feet and its width 42 feet.

37.verse: The entrance room faced the outer courtyard. Palm trees were carved on the walls along the passageway. Eight steps led up to this gate.

38.verse: Buildings Near the North Gate - In the outer courtyard there was an annex attached to the inner gateway on the north side. It opened into the entrance room that faced the courtyard, and there they washed the carcasses of the animals to be burned whole as sacrifices.

39.verse: In this entrance room there were four tables, two on each side of the room. It was on these tables that they killed the animals to be offered as sacrifices, either to be burned whole or to be sacrifices for sin or as repayment offerings.

40.verse: Outside the room there were four similar tables, two on either side of the entrance of the north gate.

41.verse: Altogether there were eight tables on which the animals to be sacrificed were killed: four inside the room and four out in the courtyard.
